]]> Here's What Everyone Wore to President Obama's Final White House Correspondents' Dinnerhttp://www.esquire.com/entertainment/news/g2731/white-house-correspondents-dinner-2016-red-carpet/ http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/news/g2731/white-house-correspondents-dinner-2016-red-carpet/ Entertainment Sun, 01 May 2016 14:43:08 +0000

​This year's White House Correspondents' Dinner is also President Obama's last. Between POTUS and host Larry Wilmore, there are sure to be a lot of great jokes. And with an all-star guest list there will definitely be some great fashion. Let's see what everyone's wearing to the 102nd dinner.

]]> This Abandoned Theme Park with 'Odd Vibes' Used to Feature an Alligator Pit and a Swimming Pighttp://www.esquire.com/entertainment/g2730/abandoned-theme-park/ http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/g2730/abandoned-theme-park/ Entertainment Wed, 27 Apr 2016 19:43:00 +0000

An amusement park that opened in 1951 and was once "full of life" for photographer Andy Heatwole later became a "haunting" place of serenity.

The now-long-gone Aquarena Springs acted as Heatwole's eerie backdrop when he photographed the abandoned resort and park between 2005 and 2012 for his gallery, "The Ruins of Aquarena."

"It was very quiet and very peaceful, but also kind of haunting and melancholy," the San Marcos native said when describing the ambiance of the decayed grounds. "And the way the wind would come through, it would howl. It felt like you were in the middle of nowhere."

While he said the park radiated an "odd vibe" in its bygone days, it was once a staple that now brings back colorful childhood memories.

Heatwole mentioned Aquarena Springs' alligator pit, submarine theater, 220-foot high tower, skyride and glass-bottom boats were among the park's unique attractions back in the '60s, '70s and '80s.

"It was full of life, it was kitschy," he said about the park in its heyday. "It was a slice of Americana."

According to Texas State University's website, the park's main attraction was "Ralph the Famous Swimming Pig," a courageous swine that would dive into Spring Lake to drink milk from a bottle.

The park and resort were a hit until entertainment giants like Six Flags drew larger crowds with "with big roller coasters and more elaborate amusements," Heatwole said.

The era of Aquarena Springs came to an end in 1994, when Texas State University purchased the land and later converted dilapidated buildings into The Meadows Center of Water and the Environment.

​From:

]]> Follow the Yellow Brick Road to Hell in These Pics of an Abandoned Wizard of Oz Parkhttp://www.esquire.com/entertainment/movies/g2710/abandoned-wizard-of-oz-park/ http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/movies/g2710/abandoned-wizard-of-oz-park/ Entertainment Tue, 12 Apr 2016 20:52:00 +0000

For one day every year, fans of the 1939 movie The Wizard of Oz and the L. Frank Baum novel it's based on flock to an amusement park in North Carolina inspired by the fantasy story.

And, for the rest of the year, the park lies completely abandoned.​

Ohio-based photographer Johnny Joo snapped several otherworldly photos of the Land of Oz in Beech Mountain, North Carolina, during a trip to the park in 2015.​

In Joo's photos, the park lies under a fog. Dead leaves lay scattered over the park's version of the story's Yellow Brick Road.

"It was an enchanting feeling, being that the mountain was blanketed in fog that morning," Joo told Buzzfeed. "It was amazing seeing scenery practically straight out of a fairy tale being covered by layer upon layer of fog."

According to Watauga Lake Magazine, the park allowed visitors to explore the fictional land of Oz in the same order Dorothy does in the story.

The park drew 400,000 visitors when it opened in June of 1970, according to the magazine, and was considered the second-most popular park in the eastern United States.

Grover Robbins, who spearheaded the project, died months before the park opened, the magazine reported.

The park shuttered in 1980.

Fans of the Baum novels and movie still visit the park once a year during the Autumn at Oz Party.

]]> These Rare Photographs of Marilyn Monroe Are Now on Display in Londonhttp://www.esquire.com/entertainment/news/g2605/marilyn-monroe-milton-h-greene-douglas-kirkland-exhibition/ http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/news/g2605/marilyn-monroe-milton-h-greene-douglas-kirkland-exhibition/ Entertainment Fri, 22 Jan 2016 22:46:49 +0000

Two legendary celebrity photographers are united in their mutual affinity for Marilyn Monroe in "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," an exhibition showing at The Little Black Gallery in London today through February 27. The exhibit showcases some of the most iconic photos of Monroe, from Kirkland's 1961 series, In Bed with Marilyn, featuring evocative images of Monroe wrapped in a sheet, to Greene's Ballerina Awaiting Her Cue, which shows Monroe posing wistfully in a strapless tulle gown. Rarer images, including Greene's Winsome in White Fur, NY and The Hooker Sitting, LA will also be displayed.

Greene is most famous for his portraits of Monroe; he shot her on 52 separate occasions, capturing more than 5,000 photographs of the film star between 1953 and 1956. "Milton wanted Marilyn to step away from the dumb blonde thing, so he took a series of pictures of her in different characters, to show how versatile she could be," Greene's son, Joshua, told The Telegraph. Click through to see images from this series and more from the exhibit.

"Gentlemen Prefer Blondes Starring Marilyn Monroe by Milton H. Greene and Douglas Kirkland" is at The Little Black Gallery, 13A Park Walk, Chelsea, London SW10 0AJ from today until February 27, 2016.
